description_simple: Rust-like mineral that contains iron and water
mining_locations: Clara Mine, Oberwolfach, Ortenaukreis, Freiburg Region, Baden-Württemberg, Germany
supplier: Kolar Labs High Capacity Granular Ferric Oxide (HC GFO)
european_sources: https://www.mindat.org/min-1493.html; https://www.mindat.org/min-1493.html; In Germany, ferrihydrite was found in the Schmiedestollen mine near Wittichen and in the Clara mine near Oberwolfach in Baden-Württemberg, on the slag heaps of the Ochsenhütte near Goslar and in the Hölltal valley near Lautenthal in Lower Saxony, on the slag heap of the Hüstener Gewerkschaft in the Sauerland region (North Rhine-Westphalia), in the ‘Eckardthütte’ near Leimbach (Mansfeld) in Saxony-Anhalt, in the ‘Weißer Hirsch’ shaft near Neustädtel (Schneeberg) and in several mines on the Zechenberg near Hohenstein-Ernstthal in Saxony, and on the slag heap on the Kammberg in the municipality of Joldelund in Schleswig-Holstein.; In Austria, ferrihydrite has only been found to date in Rotbachl, Zamser Grund (Zillertal) and Silberberg near Reith im Alpbachtal in the Inntal valley in Tyrol.
european_locations_detail: Clara Mine, Oberwolfach, Ortenaukreis, Freiburg Region, Baden-Württemberg, Germany; Several more locations in Europe; see active mines in map; Several locations in Germany:; In Austria

comments: Gypsum is mined as a naturally occurring mineral. However, much of it comes in the form of a residual product from coal-fired power plants in Europe. Access from this source is declining, owing to the transition towards fossil-free energy production.
